articles.headline: U.S. Faults Russia as Combat Spikes in East Ukraine
articles.snippet: The accusation from the State Department said the Russian military had massed artillery and rocket systems near a contested town in eastern Ukraine.
articles.abstract: The accusation from the State Department said the Russian military had massed artillery and rocket systems near a contested town in eastern Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine — As fighting erupted throughout eastern Ukraine on Friday before a cease-fire begins on Saturday night, the United States accused Russia of joining separatist rebels in an all-out attack on Ukrainian forces around the contested town of Debaltseve.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Gene-Altered Apples Get U.S. Approval
articles.snippet: It will probably be several years before the fruit, which resists browning when sliced or bruised, shows up in grocery stores.
articles.abstract: It will probably be several years before the fruit, which resists browning when sliced or bruised, shows up in grocery stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government on Friday approved the commercial planting of genetically engineered apples that are resistant to turning brown when sliced or bruised.

articles.headline: Making Brokers Toe the Mark
articles.snippet: The financial services industry is marshaling opposition to the proposed regulation, which has been percolating for years in the Labor Department.
articles.abstract: The financial services industry is marshaling opposition to the proposed regulation, which has been percolating for years in the Labor Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you are in the market for financial advice, good luck figuring out which financial advisers are legally obligated to act in your best interest. There is a big difference between glorified salesman and true investment advisers, and yet the onus is on consumers to sort it all out.

articles.headline: In Lester Holt, NBC Gets Calm After the Brian Williams Storm
articles.snippet: Known as an unflappable pro, the newsman tapped to fill the anchor’s chair at “NBC Nightly News” for the next six months is also a strong contender to keep the job.
articles.abstract: Known as an unflappable pro, the newsman tapped to fill the anchor’s chair at “NBC Nightly News” for the next six months is also a strong contender to keep the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, just before NBC announced it was suspending Brian Williams from its nightly news broadcast, Lester Holt was told he would be sitting in the anchor chair for the next six months.

articles.headline: In Alabama City, Gay Couple Try to Wed, Early and Often
articles.snippet: Denied a marriage license on Monday by a probate judge caught between the state and federal courts, Keith Ingram and Albert Pigg have not lost hope.
articles.abstract: Denied a marriage license on Monday by a probate judge caught between the state and federal courts, Keith Ingram and Albert Pigg have not lost hope.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOTHAN, Ala. — Keith Ingram and Albert Pigg call themselves “the first denied.”

articles.headline: Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon Resigns Amid Crisis
articles.snippet: Mr. Kitzhaber stepped down amid a scandal that included a criminal investigation of the role that his fiancée played in his administration.
articles.abstract: Mr. Kitzhaber stepped down amid a scandal that included a criminal investigation of the role that his fiancée played in his administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALEM, Ore. — Gov. John Kitzhaber, long regarded as a wily survivor of Oregon politics, resigned Friday amid a spiraling crisis that included a criminal investigation of the role that his fiancée played in his administration and crumbling support from his Democratic Party colleagues.
articles.byline: By Lee Van Der Voo and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: Obama Calls for New Cooperation to Wrangle the ‘Wild West’ Internet
articles.snippet: The president signed an executive order urging companies to exchange data on cyberthreats and receive classified information from the government.
articles.abstract: The president signed an executive order urging companies to exchange data on cyberthreats and receive classified information from the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Declaring that the Internet has become the “Wild Wild West” with consumers and industries as top targets, President Obama on Friday called for a new era of cooperation between the government and the private sector to defeat a range of fast-evolving online threats.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Hitching a Toy to a Star
articles.snippet: As moviegoers salivate over superhero movies, some experts question whether the toy industry can accommodate a glut of new products.
articles.abstract: As moviegoers salivate over superhero movies, some experts question whether the toy industry can accommodate a glut of new products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Superheroes wage some of their deadliest fights on the big screen.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Gregory Schmidt

articles.headline: The Invention Mob, Brought to You by Quirky
articles.snippet: Quirky, a company that uses crowdsourcing to create and refine products, could be a model for bringing ideas to market in a faster, more efficient way.
articles.abstract: Quirky, a company that uses crowdsourcing to create and refine products, could be a model for bringing ideas to market in a faster, more efficient way.
articles.lead_paragraph: As inventions go, Jake Zien’s was a clever fix rather than an imaginative breakthrough: Irritation was the mother of his invention.

articles.headline: After the Housing Crisis, a Cash Flood and Silence
articles.snippet: The government is taking extraordinary measures to keep secret the deliberations surrounding a decision to expropriate all the earnings of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. What exactly is it trying to hide?
articles.abstract: The government is taking extraordinary measures to keep secret the deliberations surrounding a decision to expropriate all the earnings of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. What exactly is it trying to hide?
articles.lead_paragraph: On Aug. 17, 2012, the federal government began expropriating all the earnings of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance giants that succumbed to the 2008 crisis.

articles.headline: Islamic State Sprouting Limbs Beyond Its Base
articles.snippet: The Islamic State is expanding beyond its base in Syria and Iraq to establish militant affiliates in Afghanistan, Algeria, Egypt and Libya, raising the prospect of a new global war on terror.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State is expanding beyond its base in Syria and Iraq to establish militant affiliates in Afghanistan, Algeria, Egypt and Libya, raising the prospect of a new global war on terror.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State is expanding beyond its base in Syria and Iraq to establish militant affiliates in Afghanistan, Algeria, Egypt and Libya, American intelligence officials assert, raising the prospect of a new global war on terror.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Bank Hackers Steal Millions via Malware
articles.snippet: A report by a Russian cybersecurity firm says a global gang of thieves penetrated banking systems to steal millions of dollars.
articles.abstract: A report by a Russian cybersecurity firm says a global gang of thieves penetrated banking systems to steal millions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — In late 2013, an A.T.M. in Kiev started dispensing cash at seemingly random times of day. No one had put in a card or touched a button. Cameras showed that the piles of money had been swept up by customers who appeared lucky to be there at the right moment.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Gunman Believed to Be Behind 2 Copenhagen Attacks Is Fatally Shot, Police Say
articles.snippet: The police said Sunday they had shot a suspect who killed a man at a free-speech event in Copenhagen and another man outside a synagogue.
articles.abstract: The police said Sunday they had shot a suspect who killed a man at a free-speech event in Copenhagen and another man outside a synagogue.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Copenhagen police said on Sunday that they had shot and killed a man believed to be behind two attacks that killed two people, one at a cafe and one outside a synagogue.

articles.headline: In Spanish Abuse Scandal, a More Open Vatican
articles.snippet: The case, which includes allegations of a sex ring and a cover-up involving as many as 10 priests, has become one of the most serious abuse scandals to emerge under Pope Francis.
articles.abstract: The case, which includes allegations of a sex ring and a cover-up involving as many as 10 priests, has become one of the most serious abuse scandals to emerge under Pope Francis.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRANADA, Spain — David Ramírez Castillo first met his parish priest, the Rev. Román Martínez, as a 7-year-old catechism student. Later, he became one of his altar boys. Step by step, Mr. Ramírez says, the priest convinced him that to deepen his faith he should spend more time with him and the other clergy members.

articles.headline: As Dynasty’s Son, Jeb Bush Used His Connections Freely
articles.snippet: For the 12 years that George Bush held national elective office, Jeb Bush used his unique access to seek favors and make suggestions, helping bolster his own nascent career.
articles.abstract: For the 12 years that George Bush held national elective office, Jeb Bush used his unique access to seek favors and make suggestions, helping bolster his own nascent career.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stream of requests to the White House from Jeb Bush, a young but well-connected Republican leader in South Florida, ranged from the weighty and urgent to the parochial and mundane.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Sexual Abuse Allegations Against Imam Stir Rifts in Insular Illinois Community
articles.snippet: Sexual abuse allegations and a planned lawsuit against Mohammad Abdullah Saleem in Elgin have divided segments of the imam’s followers and those in the community who reject the idea that the case should be handled privately.
articles.abstract: Sexual abuse allegations and a planned lawsuit against Mohammad Abdullah Saleem in Elgin have divided segments of the imam’s followers and those in the community who reject the idea that the case should be handled privately.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELGIN, Ill. — She ordinarily did not wear a veil. But it was required at the Islamic school where she worked, and she remembers being surprised when the head of the school, a conservative imam, suggested that she remove it.

articles.headline: Museum Rules: Talk Softly, and Carry No Selfie Stick
articles.snippet: Institutions including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden have begun to adopt rules against this enhanced form of picture taking.
articles.abstract: Institutions including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden have begun to adopt rules against this enhanced form of picture taking.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a famous lab trial, a chimp named Sultan put two interlocking sticks together and pulled down an elusive prize, a bunch of bananas hanging just out of arm’s reach.

articles.headline: Terror Attacks by a Native Son Rock Denmark
articles.snippet: The police identified the suspect in Saturday’s attacks, at a cafe and near a synagogue in Copenhagen, as a 22-year-old with a violent criminal record.
articles.abstract: The police identified the suspect in Saturday’s attacks, at a cafe and near a synagogue in Copenhagen, as a 22-year-old with a violent criminal record.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — After killing a Danish film director in a Saturday afternoon attack on a Copenhagen cafe and then a Jewish night guard at a synagogue, the 22-year-old gunman responsible for Denmark’s worst burst of terrorism in decades unleashed a final fusillade outside a four-story apartment building before dawn on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Currency Battle Is Tethered to Obama Trade Agenda
articles.snippet: A growing bipartisan majority in Congress is coalescing around a demand that the president include a robust fight on international currency manipulation.
articles.abstract: A growing bipartisan majority in Congress is coalescing around a demand that the president include a robust fight on international currency manipulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A number of countries — China most prominent among them — have long acted to hold down the value of their currencies against the dollar, helping their industries by keeping exports to American consumers cheaper and making goods from the United States more expensive.

articles.headline: Cellphone Start-Ups Use Wi-Fi First to Handle Calls and Take On Rivals
articles.snippet: Two start-ups are trying to lower cellphone costs by relying on Wi-Fi routers, and now some of the bigger companies are looking to follow their lead.
articles.abstract: Two start-ups are trying to lower cellphone costs by relying on Wi-Fi routers, and now some of the bigger companies are looking to follow their lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It would not be an insult to say Republic Wireless and FreedomPop are obscure little companies.

articles.headline: David Carr’s Last Word on Journalism, Aimed at Students
articles.snippet: Mr. Carr, who died Thursday, was a funny, demanding, optimistic teacher of reporters-to-be at Boston University, and his syllabus distills his sense of an unfolding digital age. Excerpts here serve as the final Media Equation column under his byli...
articles.abstract: Mr. Carr, who died Thursday, was a funny, demanding, optimistic teacher of reporters-to-be at Boston University, and his syllabus distills his sense of an unfolding digital age. Excerpts here serve as the final Media Equation column under his byline.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Carr was known at The New York Times as a supreme talent scout, a mentor to young reporters and a blunt critic of those who didn’t measure up. He was a natural teacher, and right up until the day he died last week, he was bent on minting the next generation of journalists. Last fall, David joined the faculty at Boston University’s communications school. While David did not write his curriculum as a column, it has all the essential ingredients of one. So here it serves as the final Media Equation under David’s byline.

articles.headline: Hoping Google’s Lab Is a Rainmaker
articles.snippet: After patiently abiding a steep increase in research and development spending, Wall Street is starting to wonder when — and if — Google’s science projects will pay off.
articles.abstract: After patiently abiding a steep increase in research and development spending, Wall Street is starting to wonder when — and if — Google’s science projects will pay off.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google’s research arm, Google X, is called the company’s Moonshot Factory. One reason the company picked the word “Moonshot” was to remind people to tackle big problems that may well blow up in their faces.

articles.headline: For Hillary Clinton, John Podesta Is a Right Hand With a Punch
articles.snippet: John D. Podesta, a veteran infighter who has galvanized the struggling Clinton and Obama White Houses, is preparing to bring his strong hand to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign.
articles.abstract: John D. Podesta, a veteran infighter who has galvanized the struggling Clinton and Obama White Houses, is preparing to bring his strong hand to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not that he’s competitive or anything, but one Friday evening, John D. Podesta, a top adviser to President Obama, announced at a White House meeting that he would finish a 10-mile race that weekend in so many minutes. Needling Denis McDonough, the president’s chief of staff, Mr. Podesta added: “I don’t know what Denis is going to run.”

articles.headline: Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon and His Fiancée Walked Tangled Path to Exit
articles.snippet: A shared passion for a low-carbon energy future eventually led to a personal relationship, a blizzard of inquiries, and finally a governor’s resignation.
articles.abstract: A shared passion for a low-carbon energy future eventually led to a personal relationship, a blizzard of inquiries, and finally a governor’s resignation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALEM, Ore. — Cylvia Hayes was a long-shot state legislative candidate — armed with a passion for renewable energy and a boundless well of enthusiasm — when she first met one of the state’s best-known Democrats, Gov. John Kitzhaber.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson and Michael Paulson

articles.headline: Egypt Launches Airstrike in Libya Against ISIS Branch
articles.snippet: The move by Cairo, which came in response to the beheading of more than a dozen Egyptian Christians, threatens to draw it further into the Libyan conflict.
articles.abstract: The move by Cairo, which came in response to the beheading of more than a dozen Egyptian Christians, threatens to draw it further into the Libyan conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt conducted an airstrike against an Islamist stronghold in Libya on Monday in retaliation for the beheading of at least a dozen Egyptian Christians by a local franchise of the Islamic State, in Cairo’s deepest reach yet into the chaos that has engulfed its neighbor.

articles.headline: Aid to Needy Often Excludes the Poorest in America
articles.snippet: Government aid to low-income workers has increased, but those without jobs, who are in the direst straits, are receiving scant attention, experts say.
articles.abstract: Government aid to low-income workers has increased, but those without jobs, who are in the direst straits, are receiving scant attention, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The safety net helped keep Camille Saunders from falling, but not Charles Constance.

articles.headline: Meeting on Greek Debt Produces an Ultimatum
articles.snippet: Greece dismissed its creditors’ proposals as “unreasonable and unacceptable,” a signal that resolution of its debt crisis is not near.
articles.abstract: Greece dismissed its creditors’ proposals as “unreasonable and unacceptable,” a signal that resolution of its debt crisis is not near.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The standoff between Greece and its European lenders appeared to reach a new low on Monday as European officials handed Athens an ultimatum: Agree by Friday to continue with a bailout program or risk the funding that the country needs to avoid a default.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Liz Alderman
